Entrepreneurial-Readiness.uizard-html:
Becoming an entrepreneur is not for everyone. It takes a special person with strong commitment and specific skills to be successful as an entrepreneur.

This guide is designed to help you better understand your readiness for starting a small business. It is not a scientific assessment tool. Rather, it is a tool that will prompt you with questions and assist you in evaluating your skills, characteristics, network and experience relating to your readiness for starting a business.

assessment.question_text: Do you think you are ready to start a business?
Do you have support for your business from family and friends?
Have you ever worked in a business similar to what you are starting?
Would people that know you say you are entrepreneurial?
Have you ever taken a small business course or seminar?
Are you a leader?
Do you like to make your own decisions?
Do others turn to you for help in making decisions?
Do you enjoy competition?
Do you have will-power and self-discipline?
Do you plan ahead?
Do you like people?
Do you get along with others?
Would people that know you say you are outgoing?
Are you aware you may have to work 24/7 & 6-7 days a week, including holidays?
Are you physically fit enough to handle a “self-employed” workload/ schedule?
Do you have the emotional strength to deal effectively with pressure?
Your living standards may need to be reduced, are you ok with that?
Are you prepared to lose a portion of your savings?
Do you know what basic skills are needed to have a successful business?
Do you possess those skills?
Do you feel comfortable using a computer?
Have you ever worked in a managerial or supervisory capacity?
Do you think you can be comfortable hiring, disciplining and delegating tasks to employees?
If you do not have the basic skills needed, are you willing to delay your business plans?

ADHD-Screener.uizard-html:
If you have ADHD you are 300-500% more likely to run your own business. It is one of the most common learning neurodiversity traits, and often co-occurs with other conditions like dyslexia.

This screener is created from criteria developed in conjunction with the World Health Organization (WHO) & is designed to determine symptoms similar to those of ADHD. This test is not intended to diagnose, only a trained specialist can make a diagnosis.

assessment.question_text: I find it difficult finishing a task or project.
I find it difficult to organise myself or a task.
I find it difficult to remember appointments.
If a task or project requires a lot of thought I often delay starting it.
I find it difficult to sit still and often fidget or squirm.
I’m always ‘on the go’ and want to do things really fast.
I find it hard to remain focused in group settings.
My mind feels cluttered and it’s hard to concentrate on one thing at a time.
I make decisions quickly and fail to think through the consequences.
I am often irritable, with a short fuse.
I have mood swings, sometimes feeling quite high, other times low.
I often miss what is being said to me in conversations.
I often finish other people’s sentences before they can.

Dyslexia-Screener.uizard-html:
1 in 3 entrepreneurs identify as dyslexic. It is one of the most common learning neurodiversity traits, and often co-occurs with other conditions like attention deficit disorder (ADHD or ADD).

This screener is created from criteria developed by the Davis Dyslexia Association International & is designed to determine symptoms similar to those of dyslexia. This test is not intended to diagnose, only a trained specialist can make a diagnosis.

assessment.question_text: Do you need to read a sentence or paragraph 3 to 4 times before you “get it”?
Do you avoid situations where you’ll have to read out loud?
Do you mix up letters or forget them entirely when writing?
Do you misspell common words — misspelling them a different way every time?
Do you find yourself reading slower than most people you know?
Do you avoid projects that involve a lot of reading?
Have you turned down promotions or opportunities for advancement in your career?
Do you struggle to pronounce long words out loud, even if you know them?
Are you accused of “not listening” because you can’t summarise or recall details of a recent conversation?
Do you lose your place when reading, even if the topic is interesting to you?
Do you get lost when following directions, or confuse your left for your right?
Do you confuse or forget the names of common household objects — calling a fork a spoon, for instance?
Do you have very particular requirements for your favourite fonts, paper colour, or other visuals while at work?
